column3: Iowa) is a U.S. actor who played [[Frodo Baggins]] in [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''The Lord of the Rings'']] and [[The Hobbit (film series)|''The Hobbit'' film series]]. He is the middle of three children born to Warren and Debbie Wood
column4: who nicknamed Elijah "Spark Plug" because he was a manically energetic child.  He has a brother Zack
column5: a video game producer and seven years his senior
column6: as well as a younger sister [[Hannah Wood|Hannah]]
column7: a poet and actress who has had small roles in a number of his films. He has been a professional actor since the age of nine.

column1: While filming The Faculty he learned that casting had begun for New Zealand director [[Peter Jackson]]’s epic production of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]’s classic novel trilogy [[The Lord of the Rings]].  Wood immediately had his friend
column3: film an audition tape of him running in the fields with crudely made ''Hobbit feet''
column4: and sent the tape to Jackson.  Despite Jackson’s initial assertion that all of the Hobbit characters would be played by British actors
column5: he was immediately won over by Wood’s audition and the American Wood was cast in the lead role of Tolkien’s diminutive hero [[Frodo Baggins]].  Jackson later said he could not possibly imagine another actor in the world who would be better-suited to Frodo.

column1: The cast of the Rings movies was nominated for Best Ensemble Acting at the Screen Actors Guild Awards for three years in a row. They finally won in 2003
column2: for the third film [[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King|The Return of the King]].  For his performance as [[Frodo Baggins]]
column3: Elijah Wood was nominated by the MTV Movie Awards and for the final installment
column5: he was nominated for a British Academy Award for Best Actor.

column2: you know? That's what I love about him...he's very alive and very lively. You don't get to see a lot of that--only in the beginning of the first film--but his spirit
column4: is what holds him together.|Elijah Wood about Frodo

column2: I don't have to be a human; I have to be a hobbit. And there were things that were sort of germane to being a hobbit
column3: that was probably why it was so intriguing.|Elijah Wood on lordoftherings.net}}
